refGroup.ft: My village is Vattalakki.
From there I came by government bus number 2 to Anekati.
On arriving at Anekati, I stood for some time.
I got into the Coimbatore bus.
Then I came to Gandipuram bus stand.
When I saw Gandipuram bus stand, No. 100 bus was standing there.
I didn't take breakfast. Should be nanu - nominative case
Therefore I did not see the town properly.
After I got into the No. 100 bus and came to Pastor Ebenezer's house.
We didn't know his house.
But here and there we searched and found it.
Finding it and coming to the house at that time, when we entered the gate, the dog barked.
After some time asking, I pressed the calling bell.
One sister came.
She asked about me.
I said like this.
Then she took me to the office and made me sit.
After I sat, Mr. Jim came.
I spoke to him in Irula language and in his language.
Then we became friends.
I like Mr. Jim very much.
He is so good and white.
He said about his family.
Now I am writing stories in Irula language.
That is all.
In the morning I got up and read the Bible and prayed.
Switching on the gas stove, putting water in the bowl, putting rice and cooking food, I made the gravy.
After I finished all the cooking, I switched off the gas stove.
Then I dressed and took a bath.
I had breakfast and changed clothes.
Then I took the bag and put all the books inside.
Then I prayed.
Then I locked the house and came.
Coming by walking, we came and got onto the bus.
Then we got out at Ramakrishna Mill.
Then we came to college by walk.
I Sam am speaking.
In the morning I got up and prayed. I read my Bible.
Then I brushed the teeth and took a bath.
After that I put on all the clothes.
Then both of us had our breakfast. This may be a case of using the genetive marker for accusative meaning. Krishnamurti 2003:230 notes that dative case can be used for genetive sense.
Then the tiffin and all, we packed food for lunch.
I put the Bible and all the books in my bag.
Then both of us locked the house and came out.
After praying, we walked on the road.
Then we reached Gandhipuram by walk.
We came from Gandipuram to RKMill, the two of us.
From RK Mill we got down and then we walked to the college.
I lit the stove.
I put the vessel on it.
After the water boils, washing the rice, I have put it in. (present perfect - just now finished - Eb)
After the rice boiled, I tasted the rice and filtered it.
I took the vessel down from the stove.
Lighting the stove
Taking a vessel [with water in it].
[Putting it] on the stove, after the water is boiled, put the dal.
After the dal is boiled and cooked, bring it down.
Vegetables and all, putting in oil.
Frying with vegetables, onions, and tomato, and tamarind.
After frying and after it boils, take it down.
Making gravy [is finished].
I, Sam, am speaking.
Our house is a small house.
We are father, mother, younger brother, younger sister, two son-in-laws.
Theres a television in my house.
Television is upon the cot.
Afterwards, there are many books on the cement slab.
There are many flowers.
There is a mat.
If I haven't eat that day, spreading the mat down, I sit and eat the food.
The clock is kept on the wall,
calendar, photos, pictures.
We keep all our clothes in the corner of our house.
There are chairs.
Broom is in the corner.
Vessels (pots, pans, etc) are near to the gas stove.
Presure cooker, small dish to make curry, spoon for rice, spoon for curry, utensil for kalli (a type of food), these are all near the stove.
There is a grinding stone nearby.
All this is in my house.
This is enough. I won't tell more than this.
I Kavitha am speaking.
Our house is a small house.
There is a tv, rice dish, curry dish.
There is a masher, there is a hook.
There is a clock, calendar.
To the front of my house, there is a bapai tree. See also JPDN92.11.
[The fruit on the tree] is unripe.
There is a rolling pin.
There is a grinder on round slab.
There are clothes.
Also there are notes (notebook).
The photos are pasted (perfect) on the wall.
There is a chair.
There are clothes, jug, tub, plate, glass, mirror, window.
That's all.
My village is near the hill.
Around my village, there are so many houses.
In that, the first house is mine.
We are 5 members in my house.
In that (house), my elder sister has gotten married.
My younger brother is studying 6th standard.
Likewise I am studying in Bible college.
My father and mother get daily salary doing a job.
Every week they get 300 rupees as a salary.
We purchase all the things with the 300 rupees.
To purchase clothes and the rest of everything they need from this 300.
We are in the house this way.
We are living in this house this way.
Elephant, tiger, bear live in that place.
Our village is in the mountain area.
Ours is a small village.
In that village is our small house.
We being three people: mother, father.
My father goes to shepherd goats. (This 'kondu' is just for bringing, not an aspectual auxiliary).
My mother goes to a job, daily salary.
I have come in order to study.
There are many houses in my village.
There are many people we know.
We converse and speak with them
They also speak with us.
At night elephant comes in the fields.
We go to expel the elephant. Note: John excluded the object /anene/ from this sentence. This was supplied later.
After expelling the elephant, we go to our house to sleep.
In the morning, everyone goes to work. (perfect: They typically go gone to work)
After having breakfast, they go to work.
At evening time they come (habitual perfect) to the house.
I and my wife made a paddy in the garden that is in the field. (In reality Sam doesn't have a wife!)
We sow the seeds.
After sowing seeds, within a few days it will have sprouted.
Afterwards we have to fertilize and water the plants.
After watering the plant, within one month the plant will grow up.
After it comes up, on the plant with vegetables we must apply a little pesticide.
After applying pesticide, within three or four months, the vegetables will grow up.
After grown up, we need to water the plants. Need to fertilize well.
After three months, plants will grow.
Right after grown up, we wash the vegetables.
We put vegetables in burlap on the cot.
We keep vegetables on the cart to take to market to sell.
After taking them [vegetables], the people who like vegetables will buy.
I and my husband both work in the fields.
First of all, we plow the ground.
After plowing the ground, we put the paddy.
We pour water and sow seeds in the ground.
After sowing the small seeds, after 3 months.
After growing plants, flower and vegtables will come.
We will take all those vegetables to market and sell them.
The rest of the vegetables we bring into houses to make (sakari) and fry.
We make the vegetables as a fry, and we ate with my father and relatives all together.
We do many things with the vegetables and we eat.
In a town lived Ramu's family.
They were a very poor family. (I am not certain what morphemes this main verb consists of).
There is gas in all the houses in the town.
All was there but in his family there was none.
They cut firewood because they had to buy food for themselves.
Because there was such a situation.
At last, there was nothing in his house.
So his wife took her husband to the forest. (Or should this be alanu?)
Saying, "Go to the forest," she took and gave to him a knife, and a dhoti for [keeping] on his head, and took him to the woods.
After he was taken to the forest, he cut down and brought a creeper plant.
After getting the creeper plant and tying up all the firewood with it, having kept all the firewood on his head, he kept walking.
He came to his house and stored it.

txGroup.tx: appa ʋaɾaːgeː ʋet̪t̪u t̪iːeː poːʈu coːɾu panni.

refGroup.ft: Then taking firewood he made a fire to make rice.
And everyone ate.
I, my father, and my aunties all joined together.
Maternal and paternal aunties all joined and took the cloth on the head, and the knife, and went for firewood.
From my place to go to the hill is a little far away.
After we went to the mountain, first we went to Devil's Cave.
After we went to Devil's cave, there wasn't any firewood there.
Then we went to Banana Field near the river, and there wasn't any firewood there either.
After that we went above the perfume factory.
Afterwards we went above the perfume factory.
There were a lot of trees, and dry firewood also.
At that time were green trees.
Taking green trees off, taking dried trees off, we cut them and came.
And after cutting, coming to a place, we keep everything separately.
Afterwards everything that was picked up we bring and keep in a [certain] place.
After keeping, I went to collect the creeper rope.
When I went to collect the creeper plant, there were lots of sandal color (red) ants.
At that time when I saw the big ants, I didn't have anything to tie up with, but I collected creepers of other kinds.
Bringing them, we took 3 or 4 ropes and tied up [the firewood].
After tying, every one of the big people kept the cloth on the head.
After keeping the cloth on the head, they take the firewood and keep in on the head, and we come back. (-o: doesn't seem to be the dubitive marker here. Perhaps -om for some kind of PNG suffix.)
When we were coming back, it was so tiring.
Afterwards my firewood that I took up became unbearing.
Then we set down the firewood and went to the farm that was nearby.
We got water, brought it and drank, then washed face, hands and legs.
Then we came.
While coming, later we came to our village.
When reaching the village, my mother had kept the food ready.
After that I ate the food.
Afterwards my mother cut firewood.
Again she cooked (gave?) the night food.
Seven Brothers and their Younger Sister
In one village there lived 7 brothers and 1 sister. -mba is pet suffix
Along with them was a deer in their house. avar irukudu
The seven brothers had gone to the field to plow it. (completive, not perfective, because not talking about something that happened beforehand)
Sister would take the food for them (all the brothers).
She would give food for the deer also.
She holds the food and calls to the deer.
Oh deer, oh deer.
The deer that comes climbing on the Erukan plant.
Deer comes like wool over the Suni tree.
Climb up the Eruke plant.
Come along with the Suli plant.
Come and have food.
One day, she didn't have food for the deer.
So she completely gave the eldest brother's food to that deer.
So she only took food for 6 brothers.
So all the brothers asked, Where is the eldest brother's food? -ndu 'So'
I completely gave the eldest brother's food to the deer, she told. (That is, I gave all of the food.)
Then the brothers became angry.
One day while the deer was eating its food, (all) the brothers having hid, they struck the deer.
It died. (lit 'went death' - pocu is past tense.)
So then the sister was crying, crying, and didn't eat.
Then they cut the deer and made deer gravy and gave to the brothers.
The sister didn't eat.
After some time, she went to a river.
On the way, she saw a snake. - a water snake?
She killed it and prepared a gravy with that snake.
Then she gave the gravy to the brothers.
All the brothers ate it.
Those who ate the snake gravy died.
Then there came a time for the sister to get married.
To make garlands for the marriage, they were searching all over.
Nowhere was it available.
They saw there was a lot of flowers and plants on the grave of the brothers.
They thought that they could ask for the flower.
So they went to the mother-in-law and father-in-law of the brothers and said, "You go and ask the brothers to get the flowers."
They went, and called to the brothers, "Brothers, for the sister's marriage we have to get flowers."
We have to do the Seed ceremony. We have to make a garland. We need to do the gifting.
They told, We won't give any flower. We won't give any gifts for the ceremony, and not any garland.
Then the grandmother went, and she asked them.
That time also, they didn't give.
Then their uncle and aunt went and asked.
O brothers, O brothers, for the sister's wedding we have to give some flowers.
We have to do some ceremony.
"And we have to give the garland and ceremony of gifts," they asked.
Later they said, "We will give the flower for her, we will do the ceremony Seed, we will give the garland. avacu corrected to avalukku - is this correct? Same in next sentence.
Then afterwards, they got the flower and made the garlands. That sister got married, and they lived [happily].
Small fox story.
In a village there was a cucumber garden.
And in that garden, as soon as the vegetable grows, it goes missing.
So all have scolded the gardener. (Perhaps this is a direct quotation? "And you are a gardener!" they all scolded.)
They were not able to find out.
The gardener watched over it (for?) one day.
And when he was watching, there was a small fox inside the garden.
And the gardener asked,
O fox, o fox, in this garden all the cucumbers which are growing are all going missing.
Do you know anything? Even that also. And when the cucumber was getting ripe, someone is eating that.
Do you know who is that?
The small fox told him, I don't know anything about that.
At that time, the gardener, to catch the people who are getting the tender cucumber and eating them,
he kept in one of the cucumbers a blade and a trap. biledu optionally adds -ne per Karatti.
And then the fox came and ate all the tender cucumbers.
And then it went for another one and wanted to do a bad thing.
When it was doing, the blade trap on the big cucumber hurt the small fox.
So when it was bleeding, to stop it, the fox went to another village.
In that village was one old woman.
That old woman was grinding millet. The fox went and called,
O grandmother! Give me one fire. - originally oru ppiri - seems like a mistake
Then the old woman went to get the fire for the fox,
Suddenly the fox jumped into the grinder and scrached its back because it was bleeding millets. And all the blood and things became rough with the clots.
Then the old woman came back and gave the fire for the clots.
And afterwards when that old woman came and started grinding the millet, suddenly from there the blood came out and fell on the woman's face.
Son, I have bought toys for your sister.
Son, it's not for you.
Give definitely to your sister.
No Dad, I want this Dad.
No, I am keeping this.
No, son, tomorrow when I come I will buy for you big toys and come.
Then for you and your younger sister I will buy big toys.
Give this to elder sister.
It is a small toy, no?
Tomorrow when I come, I will buy big toys for you and come.
Then when I come tomorrow, I will buy snacks and give to both of you. (Added "both of" based on the context of the story -- only buying toys for son, but snacks for both).
I won't buy for your elder sister, because I have already brought big toys for her, no?
Ok Dad, tomorrow while you come, buy only for me. cirilapa = sari appa -ami female pet suffix (-ci in Melenadu), -imba / ippa male
Don't buy for my sister.
Sister said, "Today I want to go to the shop."
"In the shop, I want to buy all the groceries for gravy," she told to Father.
Father said, "Don't go to that shop. Let's go to this shop."
Mother told, "Today (we) don't want to go to this shop, tomorrow let's go," she told.
Then younger sister told, "Mother, we can all go to the shop together today," she told.
Then they bought all the market things and came home.
Myself and my mother went to the mountain to feed the goat.
Don't go on the rocky place to feed the goat.
My mother said, If you run the goat on the way of the rocky place, it will fall down.
Mother said, "Run the goat here."
Not that way, let's go on.
As my mother was still speaking, four or five goats fell.
They fell down from the rocky place.
After falling down, myself and my mother we ran the goat to our house.
Before we run, that's all, we run the goat.
The Word of God says,
We must honour father and mother.
We have to listen to what they say.
If we listen, and if we have a life, we'll live.
The Word of the Lord says like that.
In a village there was a headman.
In his house lived one pig and one fox.
For the headman there was some land.
In that land he made the pig and fox to work for him.
Pig had ploughed the field.
Fox was playing swing.
For however many days it was like that.
One day that village headman came to see their work, and he watched by hiding himself.
At that time this fox was playing in the swing. [a: ne:ra]-tti
Pig was ploughing the field.
The headman came back to his home.
These two pig and fox came to the house.
The village headman called his workers and told them to give hot water for bath and to give good dal cury and mutton to the pig.
For the fox he told them to give ragi porage and green's gravy.
They gave it.
After these two persons ate, fight came between them.
(The fox made a plan) to kill the pig.
Next day fox asked the pig to come to the place where the well is.
Fox asked the pig to tie a big stone on his hip.
On the hip of the fox he tied an empty pumpkin and jumped here and there on the wall of well.
Pig had fallen in the well.
Fox shouted, "Pig has fallen into the well. Please come and save."
Then all people from village ran and came.
On seeing that this fox told himself, "All the people will kill me," so he ran away to the hills.
All the village people came and took the pig out.
He died.

Tomorrow evening Velliangiri's sister comes to Velliangiri's [house] for the girl. [for his son to marry his daughter]. (Priya who is to be married is Velliangiri's daughter I think, so the aunt is coming).
Will come and make a feast.
Then from Velliangiri's house Vellingiri's sister will take Priya.
After taking her, in the bridegroom's house the wedding chain (necklace) will be tied.
On Monday after the tying of the wedding chain, by 10 to 12:30, they will be brought from the bridegroom's house to Velliangiri's house by walking.
After bringing, for all the people who gathered will be a feast.
Then they will arrange to sleep and send them next day.
Tomorrow from the morning for all who ever come and go the food will be supplied.
In Villiangiri's house marriage is going on.
After the marriage tomorrow all the people will give presentation to the couple. muluvadu 'all through the day' maiga 'gifting'
